sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Going to Councel.

sp.speaker: Abbot.
sp.p: He by this, no doubt, has both received and given good Advice.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Of whom? To whom?

lg.l: Of Rosamond, his Minion,
Who sits enthron'd, and shining like a Goddess
Within the Glorious Mansion he has built
At Woodstock: There uncontroul'd she dictates,
And he as readily obeys the Task.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: She chose that place for her Retirement.

lg.l: A Cloister had been fitter.
There with strict Discipline she might be humble;
But here she Riots in Excess.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: That I should spare her Life.

lg.l: It was good Nature, but not Policy.
I cannot speak for Tears when I behold you, Weeps.
To think what Villanies are hatch'd against you;
You and your Royal Issue are undone,
Unless the Gods be kind.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Is't possible!

lg.l: All of us are Embarqu'd in one Calamity;
The Church, as well as you, must bear her share.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: How! Where? In what?

lg.l: He cannot introduce his innovation,
His curst design of Modelling the Church,
Without Divorcing you.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Why dost thou fear it?

lg.l: If he returns Victorious, as well he may,
Since the Designs his own, then comes the Tryal,
And Rosamond succeeds Queen Eleanor.
I shiver with the dreadful apprehension;
But sure, how e'r I suffer, he will not wrong his Children.
He that will do the one, may do the other,
While his Lust flames high:
You see already, what a specious means
He takes, to blast their growing Reputation.
Come, let me tell you, that it seems to me
To be the Prelude of their Sacrifice.
No, Rosamond, the King, my self, and thee;
Nay, all the World shall perish, e'r that happen.
I shall grow Wild; I feel Distraction pressing:
I'll Stab her instantly.
You must not;
'Tis a noisy Death, 'twill make a Clamor
'Mongst the common People, and fully your good Name.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Why, would you have her Live?

lg.l: No, by no means.
She's a rank Heretick, deserves to suffer
The worst of Deaths, and feel severest Torments;
Why do I side thus with you else, but to
Inform you how to prevent yours,
And the Churches Fate? 'Twill be a Meritorious Act,
A Glorious Deed, and Heaven must, sure, Applaud,
Its Ministers of Justice.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: How! Shall she dye then?

lg.l: As Vermin do by Poison:
It makes no noise, and is a certain Servant.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: But when?

lg.l: Not till to morrow,
When the Kings absence will Assist
The Undertaking.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: How shall we gain Admission to the Bower?

lg.l: Leave that to me: Bertrard, her Confessor,
Who time from time has been my Tool, my Engine,
Shall be the Instrument to Dole the Bane,
And we, as standers by, behold the Deed.
By Heav'n! I'll have the pleasure on't my self;
From my own Hand she shall the Potion Drink,
For being my Rival, 'twill torment her more.
And I will Triumph o'r her sinking Soul,
Disturb her Dying with my Husbands Name,
Plague her with thinking she must leave him mine;
And lest the Poison too much haste should make,
I'll Henry Sing to keep her Pains awake.
And if her Vengeance from its purpose start,
Stars! 'tis your fault, I'm sure I've done my part.
Is't possible, that such a cruel Thought
Could ever harbour with my Rosamond?
Did you not see constraint in every part?
The Agony that Nature suffer'd under,
Fearing the Jealousy of an Incensed Queen?

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: Away.

lg.l: As one who views his Friend, seiz'd for a Crime
Which he himself was equal Partner in,
He cunningly insinuates to the Croud,
Sides with their Prejudice and Clamors loudest,
Till by degrees he moulds 'em to his purpose,
And, as a Stranger, pitying the Offence,
Flatters their surly Natures to dismiss him:
So I, by seeming to abhor thy Guilt,
Shelter'd my own, and skreen'd thee from her Rage.
You sav'd me from the Rack to Dye by Fire;
Preserv'd me only from her Jealousy,
To suffer by your greater Perjury.
No; I'm convinc'd you never lov'd at all,
Or else so little, you your self scarce knew it.
By Heav'n, I Love thee more than Love can speak;
My Soul's uneasy with the vast excess.
It fain would throw its fondness in thy Bosom:
It languishes with pain to tell its Pleasure.
It swells with every touch as it would burst:
It longs to speak what it can ne'r express.
Desire is over-taken by Desire;
Like Waves they swallow up each other still,
And Wishes, like the Sands, are numberless.
With Words, like these, you first over-power'd my Weakness,
Drew me to base compliance with your Falshood,
To loss of Honour, Kindred, Friends and Fame,
And yet, methought, I never should have miss'd 'em.
I found no want whilst I had Henry's Love,
But wanting that, the World is Barren to me:
Love, like a rough bred Warrior, almost starv'd,
So full was bent on one reviving Meal,
It satiated with greediness, not seeding,
And being in haste forgot its Benefactor.
But Gratitude has met me in the way,
And sent me back to pay my Thanks to Love:
Oh! Pardon then those Errors fear Created,
And let the inward Friendship of my Soul,
Plead for the outward coldness of Behaviour.
Oh Flattering Sex! whose Tongues are at Command
To Conquer still, what e'r their Hearts desire!
Why, why, ye Powers, did you on Man bestow
Such an unbounded sence, to win our fondness,
And yet so little Honour to Indulge it?
His Tongue has Charms equal to his Embraces,
And one is by the other still reliev'd,
That there's no end of Pleasure where he is.
Relentless Creature! Is this Womans usage?
Can that Divinity hear so unmov'd?
Some cursed Fiend has stoln upon thy Sleep,
And chang'd the Nature of my Rosamond.
What is it you could think to ask of me,
But I'd have granted it before 'twas Nam'd?
Wilt thou not speak? Must I begone for ever?
What! Not a look to tell me I may stay?
If thy proud Heart's too stubborn to express it,
Give me a doubtful glance to keep me here.
All! All are shut 'gainst my intreating Prayers!
Farewel then, since there is no glimpse of Comfort. Retires.
My Soul's turn'd Woman, I must ask again.
Yet, Rosamond, one Word. She's fix'd!
Oh that some Power would Rivet us for ever
Within each others view,
That she, like me, might have no other Object.
Yet e'r I go, for ever Rosamond‚Äî

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: What is it you would have me speak?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Why any thing that will excuse my staying.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: I cannot look upon you.

lg.l: Then turn away, talk to thy self:
Let me but hear thee, if I must not see thee.
Why should you tempt me to believe agen,
Only to load me with a new affliction?
Could I be satisfied‚Äî but 'tis impossible,
So we must part; there is no Remedy.
'Tis a sad Truth indeed: Part! 'tis resolv'd!
Alas, I only came to take my leave,
But fain I would have parted Friends with thee,
Because I thought I had no Friend beside.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: And could you think parting would make us Friends?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: No, but I thought our meeting might.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: Then why d'ye talk of parting?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: I know not what I talk of; any thing, let us but talk.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: Better be silent, sure, than talk of that.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Why must we not then part?

lg.l: Oh never, Henry! I can hold no longer!
Be false, or faithful, I must love thee ever.
If we must part, be't all upon thy Head!
For thus I am resolv'd to live or dye.
Then let thy Arms grow round me:
Into thy Soul press-mine: Tye 'em so fast,
That one may never stir without the other.
Oh! now my Trial comes. Heart, bear this shock,
And nothing, sure, can hurt thee.
Why d'you tremble?
Your Blood is Summon'd from your Cheeks
By some strange Call; or have I press'd too hard,
And kiss'd it from 'em?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: It will not out.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: What will not?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Fate has so order'd.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: How has Fate order'd? Oh! my Soul boads Ruin!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: I'll call it by a gentler Name than parting.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: Nothing that's gentle is ally'd to it.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: We must separate.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: Not when my Arms grow round thee.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: My Stars have loos'd 'em.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: 'Tis false, they clasp thee still.

lg.l: My Son, in whom I plac'd intire Repose,
Has cast off Duty, and now Heads Rebellion!
The Factious Clergy all applaud the Act!
His Mother knows, but softens the vile Treason!
And if the Current be'nt with speed turn'd off,
'Twill burst the Barriers of our Love for ever.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: Let me go with you.

lg.l: Impossible!
Thy tender Body cannot brook such usage,
As the Necessity of War throws on us.
I'll like a Page attend you where you go,
Run by your side, and Watch your Sleeping hours,
And in the Fight I'll always meet your Danger.
I'll step before you as your Fate approaches,
That when the God of War beholds my daring,
And sees he must through me create his Conquest,
Honour shall find it self out-done by Love,
And blushingly reverse your Destiny.
Oh wondrous Constancy!
Heav'n! Art thou not asham'd to let us want each other?
But we must bear it:
Our present pain will make our future Joy,
And to shew much of Love is much to suffer.
Within this Bower, which purposely I fram'd
For thy security, thou shalt remain;
The Labyrinths conveyance none does know
But Vaughan,
He, and thy Confessor, are all shall wait thee.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: Alas, I shall not need 'em.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Why?

lg.l: Oh! I shall never see thy Face again!
An evil Dream this Morning entertain'd me,
And now it is confirm'd.
Divert those fears, for I shall come again:
I've made a vow to Heav'n, in thy behalf,
And sure 'twill Guard us till it is perform'd.
I'm call'd; once more into thy Arms, and Trumpets sound.
Then to War. Farewel.
Nay, let me see thee to the Gates.
Let my fond Eyes the most o'th' Object make:
Oh that they could such a long slumber take,
That I, thy absence, might in sleep beguile,
Then wake to run with a transported smile,
And meet thee at thy last returning Mile.

div.head: ACT. V.

lg.l: IT must be done; there is no other way:
We must launch out, or split upon the Rock
Of her Displeasure.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: Ay, but the King!

lg.l: Fear not; the Wind sits fair, and the auspicious Gale
Will in few hours waft him to Normandy.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: Ay, ay; You've fed me up all along with Fancies, and made me believe the Lord knows what, that I should be promoted and advanc'd: I'm in a very fair way indeed, if Hanging will do't.

lg.l: The lucky hour is come, accept the Offer,
And be what thou desirest.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: What, because I'm Rosamond's Confessor, and have the Privilege of the Bowr, you persuade me to make my self a Property to the Queens Revenge, and be accessary to the Death of my sweet Charge?

sp.speaker: Abbot.
sp.p: You take me for a Villain then, it seems.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: It seems somewhat scurvily; Not that I take You for one, but I'm afraid I shall be so.

lg.l: Go to; you are to blame, and I must chide you.
What, think you I'd impose a Falshood on you,
Upon the Man I love, my Confident?

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: Oh, she's a furious Queen! I shall never forget what a fright she put me in; I am not come to my self yet, nay, 'tis a question whether ever I shall.

lg.l: I tell thee, she's a perfect Convert, Brother;
Moves with my Will, and acts as I direct.
Come, shall I tell thee why she courts this visit?
I have enjoyn'd it as a Penance to her,
To mortifie her Pride, and haughty Humour,
And work, if possible, a Change in Nature.
Where thou fear'st Danger, thou shalt find it calm
As Peace it self.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: This is wonderful!

lg.l: The tim'rous Rosamond shall be surpriz'd,
And with the Arms of Clemency embrac'd;
The Lioness and Lamb shall yoke together.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: Ay, but can it be lasting?

lg.l: My Life for't.
Mark what I say, and thou shalt find it Truth:
This Queen thou dread'st, shall daily visit her,
Condole their sep'rate Loss in Henry's Absence;
Nay, with the Bowl of Plenty shall caress her;
Each day shall still beget new marks of Friendship,
As this must usher in the happy Union.
Why this is from one Extreme to th'other:
Can Magnificent Majesty condescend to this?
You soon shall be convinc'd: See there,
I've been her Purveyor already:
Choice Wines and Fruits, the best of Nature's Store,
Are ready to Regale the fair Recluse.
Come, will you do the Office of a Friend,
Or shall I tell the Queen of your refusal?

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: Oh, no, no, by no means. (I believe he's in earnest, and I will not baulk my Fortune. Aside.) But do you really think in your Soul I shall ever live to be an Abbot?

sp.speaker: Abbot,
sp.p: The Mitre waits thy own acceptance, Bertrard.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: Why truly a Mitre's a fine thing; next to a Crown there's nothing above it; nay, I have often known the Mitre govern the Crown; and really 'tis great to govern a Crown; 'tis part of the Churches Prerogative: and though I am but a little Abbot, I shall be a tite Abbot, and the World is not over-stock'd with tite Abbots. Well, Father, I am all Obedience, I'll do't.

sp.speaker: Abbot.
sp.p: About it then.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: What just now at this minute! ha!

sp.speaker: Abbot.
sp.p: Why dost thou tremble so?

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: Cold, only Cold, nothing else. There's no going back now, I have given my promise; but my mind misgives me plaguily. If she murders Rosamond, I must certainly make up the Chorus: and if, instead of a Mitre to enlighten my Brow, I should have a Halter to encircle my Neck, Oh Lord!

sp.speaker: Abbot.
sp.p: Who waits?

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: Who are these, ha? They look terribly. That Fellow has a dreadful Cut-throat Countenance.

sp.speaker: Abbot.
sp.p: They are my Servants.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: I never saw 'em before.

sp.speaker: Abbot.
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: Bert
sp.p: Nay, be not angry, I'm ready.‚Äî Sure this Abbot cannot have the heart to murder one of his Brethren, when I am no hindrance to his Preferment. Aside.‚Äî My Lord!

sp.speaker: Abbot.
sp.p: What say you?

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: Is the Queen ready?

sp.speaker: Abbot.
sp.p: At hand.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: Sir Thomas is dev'lish Jealous; you must keep out of sight till I've secur'd him; if he sees us, I'm undone.

lg.l: Oh! fear not. Ex. Bert. with the Ruffians.
The Fool's grown troublesom and dangerous,
Too fearful, too inquisitive to live.
Therefore I've sent him on this speedy Errand.
I hope his Curiosity will tempt him
To taste both Wine and Fruit; all which are poyson'd
Beyond the reach of Art to remedy.
'Tis not improbable but he may urge her
To follow the Example of her Granum.
But say this Project fails, what then must second?
A Dagger must complete the erring Potion.
Remov'd she must be, let come on't what will;
There is no middle Course in doing ill.
What, at a loss, my Friend, my Oracle?
Is this a time for thinking?

sp.speaker: Abbot.
sp.p: 'Twas for your Service, Madam.

lg.l: I believe you, but cannot brook delay:
My Rage boyls o'er, and Nature's in a flame;
Fierce as a Tygress that has lost her Young,
I thirst for the Pursuit of the Destroyer.

sp.speaker: Abbot.
sp.p: Your Guards must stay behind.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Why so?

lg.l: They are too numerous, and will breed suspicion.
Besides, I have provided Hands enough,
And nothing's wanting but your Royal Presence
To grace the Scene.
Now, Rosamond, thy last of Life is run:
Since thy Ambition levels at my Crown,
Swift as the first Usurper thou shalt down,
To Molten Seas, and Lakes of Sulph'rous Fire,
Whose Flames are restless as thy own desire;
Seem always dying, but shalt ne'er expire.

div.stage: Scene, The Out-side of the Bowr.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: Oh, yonder he is. What, ho! Sir Thomas!

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: The Devil's in the Fellow: If a Man were not deaf, here's noise enough to make him so.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: 'Tis I, your Friend.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Father Bertrard?

sp.speaker: Bertr.
sp.p: The same.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: What Wind drives you hither?

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: A Message from the King, and a Present for the Lady.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: I'm coming, I'm coming.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: My Heart beats still; I sweat with apprehension: I should make but an ill Martyr for Religion; and to die for these Lovers would be ten times more terrible.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: What have we here, ha! I should have thought a present of Jewels had been more proper than Wine; but may be he thinks it fit she should be kept Maudlin till he return: In with your Luggage Friends.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: What, before you?

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: This is no place for Ceremony, I take it therefore.
Troop, or‚Äî

There must be something more than ordinary in this, for he never mention'd a syllable to me; yet now I think on't, Lovers are very apt to forget, and the poor Gentleman was in a strange confusion at parting: Well I'll in and examine the whole. Ha! who comes yonder! the Queen! Gods Life, there's Villany, I'll House presently and secure my Charge.
Murder, Murder.

sp.speaker: Abbot.
sp.p: Drag him to yonder Thicket. Now, Madam, all is safe, and we may enter.

div.stage: Ruff. Drags of Sir Tho. Ex. Queen and Abbot.

lg.l: Pity me rather than condemn my frailty,
And spare the rigid censure I deserve;
I cannot rest, some Devils haunt my Soul:
When late last Night I sunk to my repose,
A dreadful Vision entertain'd my slumber;
Poor Rosamond methought was all on fire,
And as I strove to quench the raging object,
The Queen threw Oyl on the expiring Flames,
And made 'em blaze a-fresh with fiercer fury.

sp.speaker: Veru.
sp.p: 'Tis but the restless passion of your Love.

lg.l: I started from my Dream, and call'd to thee,
Bad thee get Horse, attend me instantly,
And thus unknown we've posted from Southampton;
Methinks we have Rid upon the Wind, ha, Verulam,
I scarce could feel the speed my Spurs created,
And yet methoughts 'twas a slow pace to Love
It is not fit that I dispute your will,
Tho' I could wish, nay, do with all my Soul,
This Ague fit of Love had never seis'd you;
For by it, you may lose the bless'd occasion
That time e're offer'd to surprize your Foes.
Tell me no more of Foes while she's in danger,
For, oh my Soul is Wedded to the Fair,
Whose Power is boundless as her Beauties Charms;
When I would go, there's something holds me back;
Even while I talk, my boding Heart, with more
Than usual fierceness, beats its time,
As if that Life were on the hurry.
Why this cold Dew, which flows from every Pore?
Why do I tremble thus?
Surely the Earth suffers the throws of Labour,
And some strange Birth starts forth to view the World.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Imagination gains upon you, Sir.

lg.l: Ha! Is't not Blood?
By Heav'n a mighty Tract! Where is the source?
Search! find it out! I'm on the Rack! They search and drag in Sir Tho. Vaughan.
Am I to blame now, Verulam?
Oh, speak! Where is my Soul? my Love? my Rosamond?

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: I shall never recover.

lg.l: Say, is she living? Answer me quickly,
If thou'dst save the King.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: The Queen and Abbot‚Äî

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: The Devil.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Ay, and his Dam too, they have maul'd me.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Force open the Doors.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Impossible! the means are wanting.

lg.l: Would I have answer'd so to Verulam?
To thy Relief I would have added Wings.
Would I had Men, not Walls, to Combat with!
With my keen Sword I'd hew a passage through!
Spight of all opposition force my way,
And from the Harpies Talons snatch the Prey.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Gently, gently, good Gentlemen, I shall reach my Journies end soon enough. If the King does force in, and my Life keeps my company so long, I would fain see my self Reveng'd on this Damn'd Abbot.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Will you not be dress'd, Sir, you may recover?

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: No, I'm past the Cure of a Salve-dauber, would I had the Grace to ask Pardon for my Sins: But I have put off my Repentance as I us'd to do my Bus'ness, till the last hour, and now I'm hurried to the Devil at a moments warning! Softly, good Sirs, softly.

lg.l: You have remov'd the Mist of my Offences,
Which, like a Cloud, ascended up to Heav'n,
And hinder'd all my Prayers from being heard.
How willingly could I relinquish Life!
Part with this wretched Being! and for ever,
Within the Earth's cold Womb, contented lye?

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: Have you a mind to destroy your self? Go to, you're to blame; by my Order you are. What! spoil that pritty face with whimpering, and crying, for a little Absence?

lg.l: I am miserable, Father! A lost Creature!
For all the comfort of my Life is gone!
The Sun has left the Horizon, and I,
Like those who live under the Frozen Pole,
Am now all Darkness, Horror and Confusion.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: He'll return, I warrant thee, speedily; he can't live without you. You're the Apple of his Eye, the Joy of his Heart, the Lamp of his Life, and he'll bring Oil to feed it, I'm certain‚Äî If the Queen should bolt upon us, while she's in this humour, 'twou'd scare her out of her Wits; there's no perswading her to Reason: I'll see what a Comfortable Dram will do. Why, Madam! Madam! you have forgot what the King sent, he foresaw there would be occasion, and, like a prudent Man, provided against a Rainy Season; see how it sparkles, 'tis as bright as your Eyes: Opens a Flask of Wine and fills. As red as your Lips. Now cannot I forbear His Majesties Health: May he live for ever.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: Heav'n say, Amen.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: 'Thas an odd sort of a Farewel‚Äî I can't imagine what growth this Grape is of‚Äî 'tis not Burgundy. Gad shall save me, it warms one strangely; such a twang I have not met with: I must cover His Majesties Health with your Ladiships. Come, bless both! bless both!

lg.l: What stately Rooms! what glorious Apartments!
How Furnish'd! how Adorn'd! These shew a Grandeur,
Fit for the Empress of the Universe.
Love always serves his Minions at this Rate,
And 'tis her turn to be ascendant now.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Not, and I live, my most Officious Sir.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: The Queen!

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: Ha! how terrible she looks.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: An unexpected Visitorit seems.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: Where is my Guardian? Where my Servants?

sp.speaker: Abbot.
sp.p: They're gone before to Usher you the way.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: I am Betray'd! Undone!

lg.l: Thou art, indeed.
Thy Guilt arraigns thee, and thy Conscience has
Pronounc'd against thy self the fatal Sentence:
Here all thy Glories mingle with the Dnst.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: Oh Lord! what will become of us, she's got into one of her mad Fits again? I'm ruin'd! A lost Man!

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: What means my Queen?

lg.l: No, you mistake, I am the Slave, you are the Queen,
For all of Majesty, of Power, and Pomp,
Are Center'd by my Lord, the King, in you;
I servilely attend your leisure hours,
And humbly wait upon his idle pleasures.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: Here will be Murder; I'm in a Sweat already.

sp.speaker: Abbot.
sp.p: Peace, Fool.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: Peace Fool! Where is't? here's no likelihood of Peace; here's nothing but Fire and Tow, and I burn already.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: Will you but hear me?

lg.l: No, 'tis in vain, thy bounds of Life are set;
Thou dyest Usurper.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: Yet stay, one Word before you strike the blow.

lg.l: She is not fit to live, therefore dispatch:
Strike home, and while she's studying for a Lye,
Let her sink quick to Hell and tell it there.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: The King.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Ha! where?

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Is upon Entrance.

sp.speaker: Abbot.
sp.p: Has mischief plaid the Jilt?

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: Oh luckly Minute!

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: Welcom, dear King; but I burn confoundedly.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Thou shalt not scape.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: You will not Murder me!

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Hadst thou ten thousand Lives, here they should end.

sp.speaker: Abbot.
sp.p: We trifle time away.

lg.l: To let thee see I yet am Charitable,
And would not kill but on Necessity,
Here, take thy choice, Drink this, and linger out
A moments space.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: Yet Mercy!

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Here's all I have.

lg.l: Oh, hold! Give me the Cup! The Dagger gives
Immediate Death, and I shall perish e'r I see the King...

sp.speaker: Abbot.
sp.p: What, will you spare her?

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: No‚Äî Drink or‚Äî

lg.l: I do. Thus I submit, and Drink the Bane of Life;
The Bane of Love. Oh Henry! thus I fall thy Sacrifice.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: What! Do I see the same Wine I drank? Oh! My Bowels!

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Rise, Rosamond.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: Only to fall again? No, I am down for ever.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: Is the Wine Poyson'd, no help?

sp.speaker: Abbot.
sp.p: None; you must be tasting, fall to your Prayers.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: I've none of my Beads: Oh! I'm gone! I'm dying! I'm dead!

sp.speaker: Abbot.
sp.p: Lead the Fool out; let not his noise disturb us.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: Oh, Gentlemen, what will become of my Soul? What will become of my Soul? Take notice, Friends, that I dye in doubt! I dye in doubt! for I don't know where I'm going.

lg.l: Am I then come too late? And is my Rose,
My lovely Rose, torn short from off the Stalk?
Look up my Love, and bless me with thy Eyes;
Oh, gaze upon me while their lustre last,
And when they close, I'll sink in darkness with 'em.
I do, I must while I have any being;
But, Oh, the date is short, yet I am blest
That I expire within your Royal Arms.
Open the snowy Mansion of thy Breasts,
Where Natures everlasting matchless sweets
Shoot forth, to bless the sence that can approach 'em.
Oh, shew me where the bleeding sluces are,
That I may piece-meal tear my trembling Flesh,
To stop thy flowing Life.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: I have no wounds.

lg.l: Why then dost thou talk of dying?
Why stretch my Soul upon the Rack of Tortures?
Oh, most detested sight;
Curse on my Hand that spar'd the Object
Which so much torments me.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Help me to rear her.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: Oh, If I stir I die, my Dear, Dear Henry.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: What?

lg.l: I'm Poison'd; Let me embrace you for the time
I stay, and breath my Soul out here, for 'tis on wing.
Some run with speed, and call assistance hither,
My Crown to him that saves her.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Thank you Gentlemen for your good company hither, I am travailing; the Abbot, that Spiritual Guide, has given me a wrong Pass, a Pox on him.

lg.l: While Fate is busie, I will shift the place,
It grows too hot for me.
Your Pardon Sir, As the Abbot is going, Verulam stops him.
We must not part yet.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: No, hold him good Verulam; let not the Layety be ever the sufferers; let the Church have her share of this mischief, that she may not laugh at us always.

sp.speaker: Abbot.
sp.p: An Ax, a Gibbet, or a Wheel; Oh, scandal of my Tribe, to be thus caught.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: Have I your hand?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Why, dost thou question it?

lg.l: A sudden mist intrudes upon my sight,
My Limbs grow numb; I shiver with the cold,
Cold touch of Death; Oh; help me, clasp me hard;
A tall lean shade is plucking me away:
I must along with him.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Oh, dreadful sound!

lg.l: Remember me a little amidst your Joys her eafter,
Indeed I'll think on you; Oh, in my Grave, when you
Expire, be laid; I'll keep it warm against your coming.
I'm very sick‚Äî my pain's exceeding great‚Äî
But yet I love, believe me that I love, Farewell.
Oh, one word more, my Rosamond, one more,
She's gone, the Beeuteous frame's dissolv'd,
Life is no more; And what is Life without her?
Now for Medusa's Head to work a change,
That I might grow a Statue by her side,
And be each others Monument for ever.

sp.speaker: Veru.
sp.p: My Royal Lord,

lg.l: What wondrous sweetness dwells upon her Lips?
Tho' Death has Ravish'd hence the blooming Rose,
The Lillies spring afresh‚Äî but a pale yellow
Steals upon their Beauty, and, with the Setting-Sun,
They seem to wither.

sp.speaker: Veru.
sp.p: Sir, I beseech you;

lg.l: Oh, Verulam, behold! how Nature struggles,
The Red again seems to assume her Cheeks,
And Death's unwilling to perform his Office;
He's stept to Heav'n to beg her a Reprieve:
Life, like a Lambent Glory, Dances round her,
And waits for fresh admittance.

sp.speaker: Veru.
sp.p: Will you not hear me Sir?

lg.l: The Gods were deaf to me when I complain'd,
And I will now be so to all the World.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: May I not speak?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: And justify the Murder: Hence, begone.

lg.l: No; as an expiation for the fact,
Here take my Life, but spare my Children.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Ha! what say you?

lg.l: Our easie Natures were impos'd upon,
Abused by yonder. Villains sophistry;
Had he ne're blown the Embers of Suspition,
That you design'd to Ruin them and me,
These Hands had ne're been stain'd with Blood.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Speak Fury, What could urge thee to this deed?

sp.speaker: Abbot.
sp.p: Remember Becket- and then shake with horror.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Away with him to death.

lg.l: Thou dar'st not kill me Henry;
Too much o'th' Churches Blood hangs on thy Head:
If thou tak'st mine 'tis multiplying Murder.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Thou shalt not live, tho' I appeal unto his Holiness.

lg.l: That's asking my Fellow if I'm a Thief.‚Äî
There's Justice cheaper for you: Stabs the Abbot, who falls.
Sink Pulpit-Furniture.

sp.speaker: Abbot.
sp.p: 'Tis done, and all your torturing Projects are prevented: But Monarch, here I Prophesie thy Ruin! To Becket's Shrine thou must a Pilgrim go, the Church has vow'd it; shun it if thou canst. And next thy Son; Thy Son shall wear thy Crown in thy own Life time. Becket, thy Hand, and Guide me, for I'm coming.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Can Wickedness, like thine, e'r hope for Heav'n?

lg.l: No matter what I hope for, this I know,
Thy Plagues on Earth will equal mine below.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: So, here's a Temporal Pimp by a Spiritual Knave, and how to get to Heav'n without him will be hard.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Poor Sir Thomas.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: As rich as I was Born, the Earth has her own again, and I owe the World nothing.

lg.l: Behold what thou hast done, unthinking Woman!
Thou wretched Instrument to yonder Villain!
Prithee begone, lest that my trembling Hand
Rush on a Deed unworthy of my self.
I go, and if thy Rage will banish me for ever,
It will some pleasure to my wrongs appear,
As I must ne'r have thee, thou canst not her.
Oh, Rosamond!
What Wonders would I do to purchase thee again!
Take Comfort, Sir, since she is past restoring:
Let War, and thoughts of Conquest, drive her from you.
Your Country wants you, and your Honour calls,
If you'd do something to Revenge her loss,
Now is the time; your Son invites you to't.
We'll raise a Funeral Pile of Norman Rebels,
And burn 'em to the memory of her.
I thank thee, Verulam, thou hast awak'd me;
Let's hasten to Erect that Monument.
Oh Rosamond! thou shalt be Nobly follow'd;
Of my own Bowels I will make Attonement!
And my Curs'd Queen shall find her Rage outdone,
For I'll Revenge thy loss upon her Son.
